tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: Macro analysis helps us understand __________ risks and design stress scenarios, while bottom-up monitoring of volatility informs us about __________ risk and is useful for __________.

parts.content: Micro and Macro perspectives are __________ and inform each other.
Volatility measures … (mark all that apply)

choices: low levels of perceived risk
low levels of perceived risk and potentially high levels of hidden risk
hidden risk could be an issue
parts.content: Low market volatility and VaR implies … (mark all that apply)

choices: can lead to complacency
make it easy put on leverage
can sow the seeds of magnified future risks
are a great time to search out hidden risks
parts.content: Periods of low volatility … (mark all that apply)

choices: can present contrarian opportunities
require continuous monitoring of markets
parts.content: High levels of volatility … (mark all that apply)
Please match the following terms to describe early warning signals.
values: Clustering
Expanding Waves
Super-Exponential Increase

choices: super-exponentially increased (much more than doubled)
parts.content: Assume that you have defined a 10% loss threshold for Chinese Equities (FXI ETF), which currently represents a DStress of 10. Over the next month, DStress declines to 5. This implies that the PStress has likely:
The most important driver for StressGrades is
PStress for major ETFs increased super-exponentially before the onset of the subprime crisis.
A broad decline in ETF volatility preceded the March 2009 market bottom.
PStress is a measure of potential, or hidden risk.
Low PStress indicates low risk.
A major objective of PStress is to enable risk managers to sense and respond to emerging risks.
Match the pairs.
values: Early warning
Potential Systemic Risk
StressGrades™

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: Does this imply that the risk of fixed income instruments is low?

parts.content: Micro: Visible risk is _____________.
Macro: Potential risk is ____________.
Corporate bonds looks like a ______________ trade.
Now assume corporate bonds sell off on August 3: StressQ jumps to 99, DStress drops 30+%, PStress up over 100% for LQD, JNK. This would be an ____________ signal.
What would reconfirm your assessment? (mark all that apply)

choices: Increasing credit spreads and defaults

Flight to safety: increasing credit spreads, decreasing government bond yields, equity downside shock and broad decline in risky assets globally (i.e., commodities, carry currencies), spike in volatility
Liquidity shock requiring more expensive funding and selling of assets
Decline of safe haven currencies such as CHF, USD, JPY
parts.content: As a bank risk manager, what scenarios would you emphasize? (mark all that apply)

choices: Accurately predict and control risk
Proactively sense and respond to emerging risks
parts.content: Our risk management paradigm can best summarized as
Please rank in order of priority.
values: Address escalating high likelihood and impact stress themes
Focus attention on emerging risks while they are still manageable
Accurately quantify the probability of stress events

parts.content: Please match the term with its definition.
values: Describes the number of standard deviations a scenario is from a predefined stress threshold
A metric of the market implied probability of a stress event
A percentile measure between 0 and 100 which measures the visible risk of a stress theme

choices: Bonds, because low StressQ indicates potentially high hidden risk
Commodities, because high StressQ indicates elevated levels of volatility
parts.content: Assuming you hold all of these assets in your portfolio, what should be your first focus:
Which asset class has the highest relative level of hidden or potential risk?

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: How might you group these scenarios to avoid tracking all 29 scenarios? True or False

parts.content: Consider the current PStress of all scenarios and separate by quintile.
Group highly correlated scenarios / themes.
Plot DStress over time and visually identify scenarios that move closely together.
Assuming you could proxy these scenarios into 5 groups, what would be your next steps?
values: Identify the highest PStress / smallest DStress scenario in each group to track
Seek to understand how the portfolio is vulnerable to archetypal scenarios
Monitor outlier movements of archetypal scenarios

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: True or False: For reverse stress testing, if the portfolio changes, we

parts.content: need to identify new reverse stress scenarios
need to monitor new reverse stress scenarios
can use the same reverse scenarios universally
“Dynamic Steering” implies adjusting trajectory with __________ feedback.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: Phase transition dynamics imply there is a __________ window of opportunity for exerting control, and __________ action is essential.

parts.content: Which of the following are systemic fault lines in financial markets? (mark all that apply)

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: The following questions refer to the graph below.

parts.content: What are the highest priority scenarios
What are emerging risk scenarios
ETFs at the center of the network show ______ correlation to other assets.
ETFs consistently at the periphery tend to be ______ systemic risk diversifiers.
With the node length representing correlation, we would expect the network to ______ as systemic risk escalates.

choices: practical to implement as scenarios are readily available
can provide useful contextual insights about risks
useful for quantifying portfolio correlations
while history may not repeat itself, it often rhymes
parts.content: What are advantages of using historical scenarios? (mark all that apply)

choices: history is unlikely to repeat itself exactly
can create a false sense of confidence
may not be appropriate for current conditions
challenge of incorporating new assets
challenge of filling in missing data points
parts.content: What are some limitations of using historical scenarios?

choices: it’s incomplete, and omits important qualitative perspectives
ignores Black Swans, e.g., extreme tail scenarios that have not happened.
models are not useful in forecasting risk
objective approaches are based on limited assumptions
parts.content: What are some potential limitations of purely objective approaches to stress testing?
In John Mauldin’s case study (slide 25), which country’s projected debt to GDP ratio resembles most like Greece?

choices: scale sensitivities to market conditions
focus on correlation effects with sensitivity analysis
consider the interaction of multiple factors
parts.content: What are key BIS recommendations about stress testing related to sensitivity analysis? (mark all that apply)

choices: ability to apply to all major risk factors
applicable on both an individual position and portfolio basis
useful for quantifying portfolio effects
parts.content: What are advantages of sensitivity analysis? (mark all that apply)

choices: cannot be applied on a portfolio level
cannot be used for multiple factors
does not incorporate probabilistic views
does not incorporate portfolio effects (correlations)
not useful for identifying non-linearities
parts.content: What are limitations of sensitivity analysis? (mark all that apply)

choices: Excessive risk concentrations, especially in subprime securities
Tension between earning revenues and acting in the best interest of clients
parts.content: What proved to be the greatest vulnerability for Goldman Sachs during the GFC?
In a declining yield environment, many investors have flocked to corporate bonds as a perceived safe haven. Investors should be wary of [mark all that apply]:

A Facebook executive wishes to structure an equity swap with GS which involves receiving the return on FB and paying LIBOR interest rate. As collateral, he offers his FB stock holdings. Which risk reporting limitations should GS focus on:
An integral approach can be described as: [mark all that apply]

choices: combines multiple perspectives into a single perspective
recognizes that any single perspective is at best true but partial
considers multiple interdependent perspectives to get a more comprehensive view
is a universal framework that can be applied to any discipline
parts.content: Integral theory... [mark all that apply]

choices: Subjective Interior and Objective Exterior
parts.content: What are key dimensions in the Integral Quadrants? [mark all that apply]

choices: develop idiosyncratically without any discernible stages
eventually reach a fixed developmental plateau
develop in specific stages, but not necessarily in a sequential progression
progress through sequential stages of development
parts.content: Developmental psychology finds that individuals and organizations
Match key perspectives with statements.
labels: I don’t trust statistics. Risk management to me means knowing the fundamentals of the businesses I invest in intimately.
We measure and control risk.
Risk management is both an art and a science.
values: Objective
Subjective
Integral

choices: more lines of intelligence leading to better decisionmaking
greater diversity leading to suboptimal decision making
parts.content: Some years ago, the Norwegian Sovereign Wealth Fund (NBIM) surprised the investment world by appointing an ethicist as a senior investment officer. The implications of such a decision were likely: [mark all that apply]

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: What appears to be InX’s risk management stage of development?
InX appears to suffer from each of the following:

choices: High risk of GroupThink and overconfidence
Excessive trust in risk quantification using actuarial models
Limited perspective taking, especially with regards to potential (invisible) risks
Likely breach of regulatory rules and policies due to weak internal limits and controls

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: Which of the following individual risk reduction mechanisms can amplify risk if adopted collectively [Mark all that apply]

choices: Extending liquidity through longer term borrowing
Portfolio insurance through delta hedging
Reduction of leverage by selling assets

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: Trend following strategies ______ systemic risk while contrarian investments ______ systemic
What is the systemic risk impact of following strategies? Write “amplifies” or “dampens”.

parts.content: shorting into a bull market and buying into a bear market
buying VIX below 15 and selling VIX on spikes above 25
momentum trading (i.e., buying on rising prices and selling on falling prices)
buying deep value stocks and shorting overvalued stocks
dynamic portfolio rebalancing to keep a consistent asset allocation

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: What are some examples of coupled risks [mark all that apply]

choices: homogenous financial institutions with similar assets and funding sources
industrial agriculture, with 4 monocultured crops representing a majority of the world’s food supply
extreme economic export or import dependence
a world economy dependent on fossil fuels for energy
feature a multiplicity of diverse and interdependent elements
are complicated and difficult to understand
are driven by amplifying and dampening feedback loops
parts.content: Complex systems (mark all that apply)

choices: Failure of systems to adapt
Difficulty understanding the mechanics of the system
parts.content: Major problems with complexity include (mark all that apply)

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:PRMIA-NAQ-PR.content: We are seeing a paradigm shift from “Predict & Control” to “______&______”, where management can be viewed as ____________ steering.

parts.content: Please match the blanks for Visible vs Potential positive and negative attributes for each polarity in the chart below:
values: Forward looking, considers hidden structural risks
Present oriented, manage risks that matter now
May be too theoretical and fail to prioritize issues that need immediate attention
Myopic and reactive to current environment

parts.content: Please match the blanks for Tactical vs Strategic positive and negative attributes for each polarity in the chart below:
values: Slow to respond to changing conditions
Myopic, unable to view long term opportunities
Fundamental big picture perspective
Dynamic current view of portfolio and markets

choices: short term stability at the expense of long term stability
short term instability but longer term sustainable markets
ever greater asset bubbles and busts
parts.content: Downsides of asymmetric central bank policy include: [mark all that apply]
Which of the following mechanisms can lead to financial instability? Select all that apply.
parts.explanation: Amplification feedback, delays in feedback loops and leverage can all lead to financial instability. Central bank intervention can lead to financial instability only if asymmetric. Symmetric action increases stability.

choices: In the long run, we are all dead
Markets should be laissez-faire and they will self-govern
Booms occur because of the expansion of the money supply
parts.content: How would you best summarize Hyman Minsky’s most famous hypothesis?
Who do we monitor for Early Warning of emerging scenarios?
Tipping points are levels at which the momentum for change is ______.
Who do we consult to generate stress scenarios?

choices: super exponential rate of change
parts.content: Quantitative signals observed during Tipping Points: [mark all that apply]

choices: an extreme event has happened
a phase transition could be imminent
the distribution may have changed
we should not observe outliers if risk models are correct
parts.content: Outliers are significant because: [ mark all that apply ]

choices: a test of model validity
a worst case loss estimate
parts.content: Outliers can be used as: [mark all that apply]

choices: Confirmation of a phase transition
Increased chance of regime shift
Increased chance of mean reversion
The statistical distribution has shifted
parts.content: What could outlier clustering signify? [mark all that apply]

choices: Increased cross border asset flows
Asset bubbles, especially in real estate
parts.content: Which of these are common factors driving banking crises?
Banking crises are often followed by _________ crises.
Which of the following scenarios is most likely after a banking crisis?
What was the average range of GDP growth in the US after the tech bubble if we subtract Mortgage Equity Withdrawals?

choices: Interest rate hikes if the majority of your debt is in local denominated currency
parts.content: Which of the following are the most traditional ways of neutralizing debt crises? Select all that apply.

choices: Rapid crystallisation vs Protracted impact
parts.content: FSA recommends considering which of the following dimensions for generating reverse stress scenarios? (mark all that apply)
FSA’s reverse stress cycle includes … (mark all that apply)

choices: Impact business strategy and risk appetite
Introduce additional monitoring and triggers
Enhance and inform existing stress tests
parts.content: FSA recommends using the output of reverse stress tests to … (mark all that apply)

choices: Scenarios are analyzed and escalated up the chain of command
Macro scenarios are prescribed by risk managers and sent down the hierarchy for traders to analyze
parts.content: How does JPM leverage its institutional hierarchy in the RST process?

choices: Yes, traders could omit key scenarios
No, RST is an objective process which would flag omissions and inaccuracies
parts.content: Can RST be gamed by traders?

choices: No, potential gaming is unavoidable and therefore limits the usefulness of RST
Yes, other risk metrics can be used to judge the quality of submissions, and insincere submissions could identify potential rogue traders
parts.content: Can RST’s vulnerability serve to improve risk governance?

choices: The first step for RST is to specify a threshold loss amount.
RST uses historical stress scenarios to generate loss estimates.
The goal of RST is to identify key scenarios that could lead to major loss.
RST can help identify business vulnerabilities.
Regulators require RST to be published in annual reports.
parts.content: Please mark all that are true.
